title: Here's a big reason why people may be gloomy about the economy: the cost of money
description: Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers argues that high interest rates are contributing to people's gloomy economic mood. Sentiment may improve, though, if the Federal Reserve begins to cut rates.

title: Supreme Court to hear arguments in Trump immunity case in April
description: The order from the court Wednesday keeps Trump's prosecution in the Jan. 6 case on hold.

title: Supreme Court seems torn over bump stock ban
description: In 2018, the federal government banned bump stocks for that reason, but gun enthusiasts have challenged the regulation in court, contending that only Congress has the power to enact such a ban.

title: Comedian Richard Lewis, who recently starred on 'Curb Your Enthusiasm,' dies at 76
description: Lewis was an acclaimed comedian known for exploring his neuroses in frantic, stream-of-consciousness diatribes while dressed in all-black, leading to his nickname "The Prince of Pain."

title: Missouri advocates gather signatures for abortion legalization, but GOP hurdle looms
description: Missouri has one of the strictest abortion bans in the U.S. Abortion rights supporters have until May to gather over 171,000 signatures to have the issue appear before voters this fall.

title: More than 330,000 Jeep Grand Cherokees are recalled to fix steering wheel issue
description: Chrysler is recalling more than 330,00 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of a steering wheel issue that may cause drivers to lose control of their vehicles.

title: How can you make the most of leap day? NPR listeners have a few ideas
description: We get a leap day only every four years. How will you spend it? Here's some inspiration from people celebrating all sorts of personal milestones — and those who just want to enjoy their extra day.

title: Biden is getting a physical. The report will be scrutinized because of his age
description: President Biden, 81, is the oldest person ever to hold the office, and voters have expressed concern that he is too old for a second four-year term in the job.

title: 'Uncommitted' voters send Biden a message on Gaza; Alabama senate moves to protect IVF
description: Biden and Trump win Michigan's primary, but "uncommitted" voters send Biden a message about his support for Israel. Two Alabama senate bills aim to protect IVF treatments in the state.

title: Michigan could help decide the presidency. But many there aren't excited to vote
description: NPR spoke to autoworkers, college students and Black churchgoers in the Detroit area about the general election. Many aren't excited about their likely choices, with some unsure they'll vote at all.

title: A half-century later, students at the University of Mississippi reckon with the past
description: University of Mississippi students meet members of the school's Black Student Union from 1970. They were jailed and expelled from Ole Miss for protesting token integration.

title: Christian nationalism's support is strongest in rural, conservative states
description: A new survey maps out support for Christian nationalist views state by state. Those views found most favor in conservative rural states such as Alabama and West Virginia.

title: In Arizona, abortion politics are already playing out on the Senate campaign trail
description: Abortion proved to be a major issue in the 2022 midterms and again in 2023. This year, the presidential race puts extra attention on the ballot. In Arizona, that means the issue is front and center.

title: Supreme Court hears challenge to Trump-era ban on bump stocks for guns
description: The regulation was enacted at the behest of President Trump after the shooting at a Las Vegas concert killed 60 people and injured 400 — in 11 minutes.

title: A tech billionaire is quietly buying up land in Hawaii. No one knows why
description: A mystery has been brewing in a small ranching town on Hawaii's Big Island. Word has it that Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff bought the land, stirring worries about what he plans to do with it.

title: The Palestinian Authority is promising change. Many Palestinians say it's not enough
description: The Palestinian Authority is poised for new leadership after its prime minister tendered the resignation of his cabinet. But it faces a steep climb to win back support from dissatisfied Palestinians.

title: Why Taiwanese Americans are moving to Taiwan — reversing the path of their parents
description: The 1970s-90s saw a wave of Taiwanese immigrants to the United States. Now, some of their children are moving to Taiwan — and navigating the complex feelings that go with it.

title: Idaho prepares to execute one of the longest-serving death row inmates in the U.S.
description: Officials say Thomas Creech's spiritual advisor will be allowed to stand next to Creech with a hand on his shoulder during the scheduled Wednesday execution. Creech has been imprisoned since 1974.

title: Idaho prepares to execute one of the longest-serving death row inmates in the U.S.
description: Officials say Thomas Creech's spiritual adviser will be allowed to stand next to Creech with a hand on his shoulder during the scheduled Wednesday execution. Creech has been imprisoned since 1974.

title: 2 men are found guilty for the 2002 killing of Run-DMC's Jam Master Jay
description: Jam Master Jay, one-third of the iconic hip-hop group Run-DMC, was killed in 2002 over a cocaine deal gone bad. A jury found two men guilty of the murder, including his godson.

title: Expanding wildfires force Texas nuclear facility to pause operations
description: Rapidly moving Texas wildfires Tuesday prompted evacuations in small towns and shut down a nuclear facility as strong winds, dry grass and unseasonably warm temperatures fueled the blazes.

title: The push to vote 'uncommitted' to Biden in Michigan exceeds goal
description: The group Listen to Michigan has been urging voters in the state to vote uncommitted on the Democratic ballot as a protest vote against President Biden's handling of Israel's war in Gaza.

title: After 10 years of development, Apple abruptly cancels its electric car project
description: The tech giant's sudden move took the thousands of employees working on the effort by surprise and sent a jolt to the automotive industry, which was closely watching the specter of an Apple car.
